III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Change of placement
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405
Section • (3) The agency shall document all the following in the
Description child's record before a change of placement occurs:
• (d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster parent put in their notice for child to be moved. There is a
licensed foster parent in the area who was an ideal fit. She knew
the child, understood and could meet her physical and mental
health needs, had expressed interest in placement, and the child
begged to be placed with her. The Associate Director of agency
rejected the idea multiple times, insisting that the child be moved
across the state to a different home, taking the child away from
her school, her therapist, and her support team in the area. After
being asked by the GAL, the adoption worker, the DHHS worker,
and the agency’s caseworker what the concerns were for the
home, the agency director failed to respond to anyone.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Care Worker was interviewed by phone on 1/7/2025. She
reported Youth A needed placement in July of 2024 after Foster
Parent 1 asked for Youth A to be moved. Foster Parent 3, who is
licensed through a local DHHS office, knew Youth A as Foster
Parent 3 used to work at Holy Cross Services – Northern
Michigan. Foster Care Worker reached out to Foster Parent 3 for
possible placement of Youth A at which time Foster Parent 3
expressed interest in taking placement of Youth A. When Foster
Care Worker approached Former Director with this option, Former
Director told her no, so Youth A was placed with Foster Parent 2,
a local foster home licensed through Holy Cross Servies –
Northern Michigan. Foster Parent 2 put in notice to have Youth A
moved in November of 2024. Foster Parent 3 had been providing
respite care for Youth A while she was placed with Foster Parent
2, so Foster Parent 3 was aware of the move request. Foster
Parent 3 expressed to Foster Care Worker she would like Youth A
placed in her home. Youth A also expressed to Foster Care
Worker she would like to live with Foster Parent 3. Foster Care
Worker reported Former Director again told her “no” to placement
2

with Foster Parent 3 after which a foster home on the other side of
the state was identified for Youth A. Foster Care Worker stated
she went to Youth A’s Guardian Ad Litem, and adoption worker
with her concerns that a home across the state was located for
Youth A rather than placing Youth A with Foster Parent 3. An
email thread with all of the above-mentioned individuals as well as
Former Director included a question to Former Director as to what
her concerns were with placing Youth A with Foster Parent 3.
Foster Care Worker stated Former Director gave them “the cold
shoulder” and did not respond to the email. Since Former Director
did not respond, Foster Care Worker made the decision to Place
Youth A with Foster Parent 3. Foster Care Worker stated this
occurred quickly as it was only a few days after Foster Parent 2
requested the replacement that Youth A was placed with Foster
Parent 3. Foster Care Worker stated Foster Parent 3 has signed
an intent to adopt Youth A, so Foster Care Worker feels there was
a delay in permanency for Youth A as she could have been placed
with Foster Parent A back in July, but she was not due to Former
Director not supporting placement with Foster Parent 3 for
“personal reasons.” Foster Care Worker added that Foster Parent
3 stated she thinks there is “personal drama” with Former Director.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed by video conferencing
on 1/10/2025. Foster Care Worker stated when replacement of
Youth A was needed in July of 2024, she needed to be replaced
the same day due to allegations made against Foster Parent 1 by
Youth A. Foster Parent 3 reached out expressing interest in
placement of Youth A; however, Youth A was already placed with
Foster Parent 2, a local family interested in adopting Youth A, so
there was no reason to consider moving her. Foster Care
Supervisor stated placement with Foster Parent 3 wouldn’t have
been an option at that time anyway as there was no time to get
borrowed bed paperwork completed and Foster Parent 3 had
placement of two teen boys, so placement of Youth A in her home
would not have been appropriate.
Foster Care Supervisor stated Foster Parent 3 provided respite
care for Youth A while she was placed with Foster Parent 2, so
when replacement was needed for Youth A in November of 2024,
Youth A expressed wanting to be placed with Foster Parent 3.
Former Director said she didn’t think it was a good idea as Foster
Parent 3 is a former agency employee and there may be a
potential conflict of interest. Youth A reached out to her adoption
worker requesting placement with Foster Parent 3 after which
Youth A’s Guardian Ad Litem sent emails about the placement to
which Former Director did not respond. Foster Care Supervisor
3

stated Youth A was subsequently placed with Foster Parent 3.
Foster Care Supervisor reported Former Director did not talk to
her much about this situation which Foster Care Supervisor
believes is because Foster Care Supervisor is friends with Foster
Parent 3. She stated it was 2-3 days at most from the time Foster
Parent 2 requested Youth A be moved to the time Youth A was
placed with Foster Parent 3. She stated there was no delay in
permanency for Youth A and placement criteria were considered
and met.
Former Director was interviewed by phone on 1/9/20254. She
stated she didn’t remember telling Foster Care Worker she could
not place Youth A with Foster Parent 3 in July of 2024. She stated
she does remember she didn’t know if placement with Foster
Parent 3 was a good idea due to Foster Parent 3 being young as
well as Foster Parent 3 having teen boys placed in her home.
Former Director stated the family with whom Youth A was placed
at that time, Foster Parent 2, was a pre-adoptive home. When
replacement was again needed for Youth A in November of 2024,
Former Director wasn’t very involved. Former Director stated she
received the group email in which she was asked for an opinion
regarding placement with Foster Parent 3 in November, but
Former Director chose not to respond because she does have
personal feeling about placing with Foster Parent 3 and did not
feel it appropriate to get involved. Former Director stated she did
not know if Foster Parent 3 was interested in adopting Youth A.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following documentation was reviewed in Youth A’s case
record:
• Youth A’s placement record:
o 5/6/2024 – 7/29/2024 Foster Parent 1
o 7/29/2024 – 11/13/2024 Foster Parent 2
o 11/13/2024 – Foster Parent 3
• Action Summaries (DHS-69)
o For 7/29/24 placement indicating move from Foster
Parent 1 to Foster Parent 2 due to Foster Parent 1’s
request to move Youth A. The following placement
criteria were scored as most important when
selecting Foster Parent 2:
▪ The case plan which includes goal of
permanence
▪ Physical emotional, and safety needs of child
▪ Least restrictive, most family like setting
▪ Continuity of relationships
4

▪ Availability of placement resources for timely
placement
• Action Summaries (DHS-69)
o For 11/23/2024 placement indicating move from
Foster Parent 2 to Foster Parent 3 due to Foster
Parent 2’s request to move Youth A. The following
placement criteria were scored as most important
when selecting Foster Parent 3:
▪ The case plan which includes goal of
permanence
▪ Physical emotional, and safety needs of child
▪ Least restrictive, most family like setting
▪ Continuity of relationships
▪ Availability of placement resources for timely
placement
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as consideration of the factors
identified in R 400.12404(4) were documented in Youth A’s
record.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
